subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. The collection of Edouard Eichwald (not examined) is stored in the Museum of Paleontology and Stratigraphy at the Faculty of Geology of Saint Petersburg State University, Russia . Syntypes of
Turritella indigena
were mentioned by Eichwald (1830) from Shukowze, Biłka, Zalisce and Stary Poczajów ( Ukraine ), middle Mio- cene, upper Badenian.

The syntypes of
Turritella pythagoraica Hilber, 1882
are stored in the collection of the Geological Survey in Vienna ( GBA 2008/028/0287, 2008/028/0288); Czepiele ( Ukraine ), middle Miocene, upper Badenian,

Revised description. Shell small to medium-sized, moderately slender, of about 16 teleoconch whorls. Protoconch unknown. Earliest preserved teleoconch whorls with keel formed by B spiral cord below mid-whorl and initially weaker C spiral cord. Neanic whorls soon bicarinate within 3 rd to 4 th whorl with moderately raised spiral keels. Weak A primary cord may occur on sutural ramp. Interspace between primary cords and broad, steep sutural ramp moderately concave on neanic whorls, becoming nearly flat on later whorls. B spiral cord usually becoming weak on late teleoconch whorls, whereas C primary cord increases in strength. Whorl profile shifting from concave with weakly incised suture to frustate during ontogeny. Secondary spiral sculpture highly variable; typically, two secondary spiral cords appear on sutural ramp and one secondary cord occurs between primary cords; tertiary cords may accompany the secondary cords. Lateral sinus angle steep, approx. 25°, deep, wide, with steep adapical part and weak adapical inflection point; indistinct abapical inflection point close to suture; distinctly adapical LS p ; basal sinus unknown. Aperture not preserved; base low, moderately convex with glossy parietal callus. Inner lirae rarely developed consisting of 3–4 weak palatal lirae and a more prominent abaxial basal spiral cord close at transition to palatal wall.

Shell measurements and ratios. All specimens incomplete, largest specimens attain about 55 mm in height and 15 mm in diameter; AA: 16.0° (σ = 1.4°), PA: 14.6° (σ = 0.9°). Lateral sinus (n = 8): LS angle = 25.4° (σ = 3.1°), LS p = 0.9 (σ = 0.1), LS d = 4.3 (σ = 0.6).

Discussion. This species is characterized by an enormous amount of variability concerning sculpture and whorl profile. In some morphotypes, primary, secondary and tertiary spiral cords attain nearly the same strength whereas in other specimens the secondary cords may be subobsolete. We have compared topotypic material of
Archimediella indigena ( Eichwald, 1830 )
from Zalisce ( Ukraine ) with the syntypes of
Archimediella pythagoraica ( Hilber, 1882 )
from Czepiele ( Ukraine ). This comparison confirmed that both taxa are conspecific as already supposed by Friedberg (1909 ; 1914 ). The vast variability documented in the available material, suggests also that the numerous ‘variations’ described by Niedźwiedzki (1886) and Friedberg (1909 , 1914 ) are mere morphs of a single, morphologically variable species; e.g.
Turritella atamanica Bogachev, 1905
, from the Tarkhanian of Novocherkassk (S-Russia) is a subjective junior synonym of
A. indigena
(see also Popov 1986 ). Friedberg (1914) similarly listed many of his taxa established in 1909 as varieties of
Turritella pythagoraica
(=
A. indigena
).

Archimediella indigena
is frequently recorded from the Eastern Paratethys, where it appears during the Tarkhanian (late Karpatian to early Badenian) and persists into the Konkian (= late Badenian). In the Central Paratethys region, it is restricted to the middle and upper Badenian (Serravallian) of the Polish-Ukrainian Carpathian Foreland Basin. Therefore, it might represent an endemic Eastern Paratethyan species, which invaded the Foreland Basin around the Badenian Salinity Crisis (
de Leeuw et al. 2010
). The Badenian Salinity Crisis led to a severe disintegration of the Central Paratethyan basins.

Archimediella indigena
has been frequently mentioned from the Pannonian basins complex (e.g. Sieber 1960 ; Švagrovský 1981 ). These records, however, represent
Archimediella carpathica
. Friedberg (1914) introduced
Turritella erronea subpythagoraica
as a varietal name of
Turritella erronea
[=
Archimediella abundans ( Handmann, 1882 )
], but the absence of the characteristic screw-like B and C spiral cords of neanic whorls of
A. abundans
excludes a closer relation. Therefore, we consider this taxon to represent another morph of
A. indigena
.

Pusch (1837) introduced the name
bicarinata
for
Turritella indigena
, although he knew
bicarinata
was preoccupied by
Turritella bicarinata Eichwald, 1830
. He rejected the already established name
Turritella indigena
because he considered this name not characteristic enough (a personal opinion without nomenclatural relevance).

Paleoenvironment. Based on co-occurring mollusc species, the upper Badenian localities in the Ukrainian part of the Carpathian Foreland Basin where
Archimediella indigena
occurs represent shallow marine, coastal settings (e.g. Nosowska 2019 ).
